prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3, long baselines
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science goal contains the setup for the observations with the long baselines at 3 mm. Since standard and non-standard modes cannot be put in one Science goal, this separation is needed.
With the long baseline observations, we will cover the spatial scales from 0.1 to 0.3 arcsec.
SgrB2 is known for its wealth of molecular line emission. In order to obtain a good continuum measurement, we choose the spectral line mode. We have carefully selected the spectral windows to exclude known strong lines.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have set up the ALMA correlator to cover a bandwidth of 1.87 GHz in each baseband, with a spectral resolution of about 3.0 km/s.
The main science driver is to obtain the continuum measurement. For that we need as wide bands as possible. However, as discussed before, SgrB2 is known for its wealth of molecular line emission. In order to obtain a good continuum measurement, we choose the spectral line mode instead of the continuum mode. We have carefully selected the spectral windows to exclude known strong lines (CO, 13-CO, c-18-O, CS, OCS, HCN, HC3N, HCO+, CH3OH, CH3CN, SO) as best as possible.
As opposed to the continuum mode, the spectral line mode will enable us to mask remaining molecular lines, that will still be present despite our carefulness.
------------------------------------- Requested spectral resolution -------------------------------------
From Belloche et al. 2013 we estimate the average linewidth to be ~7 km/s in both sources. With a spectral resolution of 3 km/s we will cover such a line with 2-3 channels.

We request and angular resolution of 0.1 arcsec, and a maximum recoverable angular scale of 12 arcsec. This can be obtained by combining configurations C36-7 (extended) and C36-1, 2 or 3 (compact). The primary beam of the 12m ALMA antennas in band 3 is enough to recover the desired regions. No mosaic is needed.
Please note, that with an angular resolution of 0.1 arcsec, we are requesting a non-standard configuration. Since non-standard and standard modes cannot be included in the same science goal, we needed to split them. Within this science goal, we are thus asking for the non-standard configuration. The justification is done for all scales.
------------------------------- Requested angular resolution -------------------------------
Adopting the nomenclature used in Zhang et al. 2009:
cloud 10-100 pc clump < 1 pc dense core 0.01 - 0.1 pc condensation 0.01 pc
The distance to SgrB2 is 8.5 kpc (Reid et. al. 2014). To sample the condensations with 2-3 beam, we need an angular resolution of 0.1 arcsec, corresponding to 850 au or 0.004 pc.
-------------------------------------------- Requested largest angular scale --------------------------------------------
There are many Hii regions present in SgrB2. In order to determine the influence of free-free radiation, we need to be able to resolve them. The largest ones covered with the proposed mapsize have a radius of 11.8 arcsec. We want to properly resolve them and request a largest angular scale of 12 arcsec.
------------------------------ Requested field of view ------------------------------
To cover the sources of interest (Hii regions and dust condensations), we need the following mapsizes (compare Figure 2):
(RA x DEC) SgrB2-N 0.35 arcmin x 0.40 arcmin SgrB2-M 0.35 arcmin x 0.38 arcmin

The main goal is a sensitive continuum observation. The requested sensitivity is 20.80 microJy in an aggregated bandwidth of 6 GHz, which will permit to detect continuum emission with S/N = 10.
---------------------------- Continuum sensitivity ----------------------------
The weakest core detected by Qin et al. 2011 at 345 GHz with the SMA has a peak intensity of 0.3 Jy/beam. We want to be able to detect this core with a signal-to-noise ratio of 10. Assuming the dust spectral index beta to vary between 0.5 and 2.0 and correcting for the different beamsize (SMA: 0.4" x 0.24"; ALMA: 0.1" x 0.1") yields a continuum rms between 0.14 mJy/beam (beta=0.5) and 20.8 micro Jy/beam (beta=2.0). We conservatively aim for the weaker value. This estimation is consistent with the predicted core strengths from modeling.
The total aggregated bandwidth is 7.5 GHz. However, being hot molecular cores, both sources will be rich in molecules, resulting in a low number of line-free channels across the total bandwidth. We will adopt an observing strategy, where we are avoiding the strongest emission lines (see correlator setup). We will then exclude all remaining emission lines, when determining the continuum using a statistical approach, which we have developed and tested with synthetic datacubes of line-rich sources.
---------------------------- Line sensitivity ---------------------------- We use the line survey presented by Belloche et al 2013 to estimate the average line peak intensity and conservatively determine a value of 0.2 K at 100 GHz. The observations were obtained using the IRAM-30m single dish telescope. Thus taking beam dillution into account, we estimate the average peak line intensity to be 25 K (beam = 25", source size ~0.2"). This corresponds to 2.0 mJy. We have cross-checked this with the line survey from Nummelin et al 1998, especially checking the intensities of the HNCO lines. They find a line strength of 1 K at 220 GHz for HNCO. These observations were obtained using the SEST-15m telescope. Taking beam dilution into account the same order of peak intensity as derived above is obtained. However, by spatially smoothing, we can reach a good S/N ratio.

The large data rate is the result of the large bandwidth that we plan to cover, combined with the high spectral resolution.
As indicated above, the spectral resolution of 3 km/s is necessary to cover the expected lines with more than one channel in order to mask them properly. The broad band is needed for the contiuum determination.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Sagittarius B2 (SgrB2), the most massive star-formation region in our Galaxy, contains two hot cores: SgrB2-N and SgrB2-M, each having a mass of ~4x10^5 M_sun. Assuming a star-formation efficiency of only 5% one would expect them to each produce a stellar mass of ~2x10^4 M_sun, putting the resulting clusters in a league with Arches or Quintuplet. The cores have to fragment to form the cluster, one expects fragmentation scales of 0.1-0.3", and masses of 100 M_sun. This is found in high resolution continuum maps toward SgrB2-M. SgrB2-N however appears monolithic. Since the age difference must be small (both sources are very close and share the same initial conditions), the question is: Why is SgrB2-N not fragmenting (yet)? Are we observing both clumps at a very crucial state of star cluster formation, one right before and one right after fragmentation? To reliably determine the masses and spatial distribution of the cores, sophisticated modeling of multi-frequency observations with sub-arcsecond resolution and matched beams is needed. Only ALMA with its high sensitivity, large dynamic range and high image fidelity is able to deliver the data needed for this transformational science.
